oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Barrs Chapel CME church: students and teachers at the school
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Barrs Chapel Christian Methodist Episcopal Church
5560 Briarpatch Lake Rd, Midway, Henry Co., TN

Black and white photograph of a school class that is part of a history of the Barrs Chapel school. According to that document "A photograph was being made of the teacher and students. There was also a Funeral that day and some of the people attending the funeral as well as the gravediggers ask to be in the picture also. Front Row: 1st little boy William (Ebb) Freeman. Third and forth little girls are Lillie Hurt and Blanche Hurt. The 8th little girl is Annie Mae Freeman the little boy beside the Teacher is Hobart (Dink) Freeman and directly to the left of Dink is Edward P. Foster, forth row center, Lucian Freeman. Fifth row center Esther Hurt, Robert Hurt is on the third row third person."

Barrs Chapel was founded on land donated for the purpose by John Barr, ca. 1864. The church and the associated school became the center of an African-American community after the Civil War as black landowners developed farms around the site. The cemetery was established ca. 1870. The church building standing on site as of 2005 was constructed in 1953 in the same location as previous buildings constructed ca. 1864, 1900 and 1933. The school was in operation by 1906 and remodeled in the 1930s, possibly through the Works Progress Administration. It was closed in 1958 when Henry County created a central segregated school. The school at Barrs Chapel was then used as a community center.
William (Ebb) Freeman, Lillie and Blanche Hurt, Annie Mae Freeman, Hobart (Dink) Freeman, Edward P. Foster, Lucian Freeman, Esther Hurt, Robert Hurt
